awd_titl_txt: Deciphering the role of comammox bacteria in nitrogen removal systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Nitrification is a chemical reaction process that plays an important role in the removal of organic nitrogen from municipal wastewater.  Nitrification is also an energy intensive process.  The recent discovery of a single organism (the comammox bacterium: COMplete AMMonia OXidiser) that can perform nitrification, has led to research into whether this bacterium may be useful for creating a less energy intensive process for nitrogen removal from wastewater.  The ability to manage comammox impact on nitrogen removal is critically dependent on a fundamental understanding of its ecology, physiology, and engineering relevance. This research project advances our understanding of the comammox bacterium by developing novel, scalable, and quantitative methods for its characterization.  The project goals are being accomplished by coupling state-of-the-art molecular, bioinformatics, and statistical methods with laboratory and field experiments. This project is yielding fundamental insights into comammox bacterial importance, ecology, and physiology and informing process strategies to exploit this novel organism for sustainable nitrogen removal in wastewater treatment plants. The research plan is integrated with a comprehensive suite of educational outreach activities involving undergraduate, graduate, and K-12 students. The activities include a blend of bioinformatics training for undergraduate and graduate students, mentoring of researchers from underrepresented minority groups, and modules for K-12 students on wastewater treatment.

Ensuring the effectiveness and sustainability of nitrogen removal from wastewater requires a detailed understanding of its biotransformation pathways. The recent discovery of comammox bacterium represents a paradigm shift in the understanding of aerobic nitrification, the first key step in nitrogen removal. The research team is investigating the ecology, physiology, and engineering relevance of the comammox bacterium in four key nitrogen removal process configurations. A primary objective of the project is to develop novel methods to characterize the abundance, diversity, and activity of comammox bacteria in complex microbial communities. A deeper understanding of the impact of process and environmental conditions on comammox bacteria will lead to improved strategies to manage and manipulate their contribution in nitrogen removal. Results of this project are advancing our understanding of the role and relevance of novel comammox bacteria within complex nitrifying communities.

por.por_cntn:
Nitrogen removal from wastewater before the discharge of treated water into the environment is critical to protect receiving waters (e.g., lakes, rivers) that may be used for recreation, fishing, or for the production of drinking water.  For nearly a century, ammonia removal (the primary form of nitrogen in wastewater) via aerobic oxidation was thought to be driven by two separate microbial populations; these were considered canonical ammonia and nitrite-oxidizing bacteria. This dogma has informed the design and operation of nitrogen removal processes in wastewater treatment systems. This project sought to advance our understanding of a newly discovered bacterial group capable of completely oxidizing ammonia to nitrate; these bacteria are known as comammox bacteria.

This project included a combination of field and laboratory-based experimental work combined with the development and use of molecular biology and computational biology approaches to improve our understanding of comammox bacteria in wastewater treatment systems. First, we developed a novel PCR-based method to accurately quantify the concentration of comammox bacteria in mixed microbial communities. We demonstrated the utility of this method by comparing the proportional abundance of comammox bacteria estimated using other non-targeted methods. This is an important contribution since accurately measuring the concentration of comammox bacteria is the first step towards understanding their distribution. Second, through monitoring of multiple wastewater treatment plants across the country we discovered that comammox bacteria are likely to be present in systems with high solids retention time (SRT); the duration a typical microbial cell spends within a wastewater treatment system. This finding is consistent with expectations that comammox bacteria grow slower than other nitrifying bacteria but also provides the minimum SRT that may be required to operate systems that utilize comammox bacteria. Third, through a series of batch microcosm experiments we demonstrated that comammox bacteria are unlikely to directly compete with canonical ammonia or nitrite-oxidizing bacteria across a range of nitrogen concentration gradients, but rather may occupy their unique niche in mixed microbial communities. While the precise niche of comammox bacteria within a complex community is still unclear, this insight is important as the co-existence of nitrifiers in a single community may provide redundancy in terms of nitrogen removal. Finally, we were also able to demonstrate that comammox bacteria exhibit surprisingly low diversity, and a single or a few closely related comammox populations appear to be prevalent across multiple wastewater treatment systems; this is in contrast with ammonia and nitrite-oxidizing bacteria where multiple populations typically coexist in a single wastewater treatment system. While the precise reason behind this low diversity is unclear, this insight would suggest that sole reliance on slow-growing comammox bacteria as primary ammonia oxidizer may affect the ability of nitrogen removal processes to return to normalcy after a process upset.

In addition to the research outcomes, this project also trained multiple graduate and undergraduate researchers, engaged multiple industry collaborators, and contributed to the development of educational modules that incorporated the latest research on complete ammonia-oxidizing bacteria in environmental biotechnology curriculum. Specifically, this project directly contributed to the training of two M.S students, one Ph.D. researcher, and seven undergraduate researchers, all of whom are from groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM. Further, support from this project enabled the graduate students to attend and present their work at national conferences and to disseminate their research at international conferences and peer reviewed publications. The undergraduate researchers were trained in a range of laboratory techniques that are routine in the field of environmental biotechnology and microbiology, along with training in state-of-the-art molecular and computational biology techniques. Outcomes of this research were integrated into educational modules taught at Northeastern University, as well as virtually delivered to graduate students as part of their graduate curriculum at other national and international universities. Overall, this project deepened our understanding of the role and relevance of comammox bacteria in nitrogen removal systems, contributed to the education and training of the future environmental engineering workforce, and resulted in new research questions that extend beyond the discipline of environmental engineering to microbial ecology and physiology.
